Content-Type: text/plain; charset="UTF-8"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

You can get notified for every post in a Facebook group by clicking the
"no=
tifications" button on the group page, but it's not possible to get
notifie=
d for every comment on every page: comment notifications are handled
by an =
algorithm (unless it's a reply to one of your comments).

Jason G.


On Mon=
, Oct 21, 2019 at 2:11 PM Jeff Clune jclune@... [neat] <
neat@yahoogr=
oups.com> wrote:

>
>
> Hello all,
>
> I support Ken=E2=80=99s suggestion t=
o move to Google Groups and broaden the name
> of the group.
>
> I also agr=
ee that Facebook has proved to be less than ideal because not
> everyone au=
tomatically receives an email/notification, since that is up to
> Facebook=
=E2=80=99s internal algorithms. I would prefer a group where everyone gets
=
> each email if that is their preference, which is not possible to my
> kno=
wledge on Facebook.
>
> Best Regards,
> Jeff Clune
>
>
>
>
> On Oct 20, 201=
9, at 11:52 PM, kstanley@... [neat] <
> neat@yahoogroups.com> wro=
te:
>
> Hi all, it's an unfortunate development and there doesn't seem to b=
e an
> ideal resolution, but I would suggest we consider moving to Google G=
roups.
> I hear some skepticism on Google Groups' own staying power, but I =
think
> they are not going anywhere because (I believe) many companies use =
Google
> Groups internally.  In effect, Google Groups is a part of a servic=
e that
> Google provides commercial users, so I think there's a good chance=
 of it
> being maintained seriously.  I find Google Groups is also well mai=
ntained
> and functional.
>
> One other reason to move to Google might be t=
hat so many people use Gmail
> and other Google tools that joining a Google=
 group would feel natural and
> easy for a new user, whereas joining a Yaho=
o group is becoming
> anachronistic, and thereby potentially inhibiting the=
 growth of this
> discussion community. Of course, we do likely pay up fron=
t by losing some
> legacy of users, but over time that loss should be overc=
ome.
>
> By the way, Jeff Clune also started a Facebook group called Evolvi=
ng
> Artificial Intelligence & Complexity (which you may also want to join)=
, but
> I am not very happy with the venue there either because it doesn't
=
> automatically send group messages to people's feeds, meaning that many
> =
posts are not seen by the vast majority of the group's subscribers!  A year=

> or two ago, I noticed a change where posts started getting far fewer vie=
ws
> even though the group membership had not decreased, so I don't trust h=
ow
> Facebook runs its groups very much.
>
> If we do try to move to Google=
 Groups, should we name the group something
> more broad, like Neuroevoluti=
on Discussion Group?  It could reflect that
> the discussion in the group h=
as broadened over time.
>
> I think such a move could reinvigorate the grou=
p over time in part by
> dissociating it from what might be perceived as a =
diminishing brand (Yahoo
> Groups).  It is unfortunate to have the topic (N=
EAT/neuroevolution)
> conflated with the health of Yahoo Groups itself, as =
they really have
> nothing to do with each other..
>
> Best,
>
> ken
>
>
>
=
> 
>
